Class GreenhouseControls

  • java.lang.Object
    • GreenhouseControls
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class GreenhouseControls
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    GreenhouseControls Class - Controls the Greenhouse and contains the entry point for the application.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      GreenhouseControls()
      GreenhouseControls Constructor Loads the GUI, sends output to textArea in GUI through GUIOutput's .setOut() method and assigns a custom exception handler for Threads.

      void getSystemState(java.lang.String s)
      getSystemState() Method Takes a String, uses it as a Key and iterates through the gcStates HashMap to print the corresponding value Example: getSystemState("Bell") would iterate through the HashMap looking for the Key "Bell" and print it's findings as: "Event: Bell - Action performed: Ring"

      • addTuple

        public static void addTuple(SystemState state)
        addTuple() Method Takes SystemState Tuple and adds it to the HashMap to save the Tuple's hardware as the key and the action it performed. Example: Key = "Power", Value = "Out".
        Parameters:
        state - The tuple you wish to add to the HashhMap.
        See Also:
        makeSystemState(String, Event)

      • makeSystemState

        public void makeSystemState(java.lang.String s,
                            Event e)
        makeSystemState() Method Takes a String and Event object to create a SystemState Tuple and adds it to gcState HashMap by calling addTuple() method. Example: makeSystemState("Bell", Bell) would create a SystemState Tuple (Bell, ring) and add it to the HashMap as Key = Bell, Value = Ring. Not used anymore within the program, Tuples are added directly from within event classes, however this can be used during restart() to create and add Tuples to the HashMap that have been dynamically created. IMPORTANT: If you choose to use this for Dynamic Events, be sure to call gcStates.clear() in shutdown or HashMap will continue to fill with duplicates
        Parameters:
        s - The name of the class/event as a string.
        e - The event object itself.
        See Also:
        addTuple(SystemState)

      • getSystemState

        public void getSystemState(java.lang.String s)
        getSystemState() Method Takes a String, uses it as a Key and iterates through the gcStates HashMap to print the corresponding value Example: getSystemState("Bell") would iterate through the HashMap looking for the Key "Bell" and print it's findings as: "Event: Bell - Action performed: Ring"
        Parameters:
        s - The Key you wish to use to iterate through the HashMap

      • gcRunning

        public boolean gcRunning()
        gcRunning() Method Checks if Threads are running Iterates through all Threads in gc and calls isAlive() method on them all, if true then it returns true otherwise it returns false
        Returns:
        boolean.
        See Also:
        Thread.isAlive()

      • terminate

        public void terminate(int delay)
        terminate() Method Terminates system normally Threads a new instance of Terminate() which proceeds to stop all threads and shuts down the system normally.
        Parameters:
        delay - How long to wait until terminate is run.
        See Also:
        Terminate.Terminate(long)

      • shutdown

        public void shutdown(java.lang.String message)
        shutdown() Method Shuts the system down when an error takes place Serializes gc to dump.out and logs the error that took place to error.log Prints to textArea what problem occured. Example: "The power went out on Wed Dec 30 15:15:00 EST 2015 (Error Code: 2)"
        Parameters:
        message - The error message given by error.

      • restoreGreenhouseControls

        public static GreenhouseControls restoreGreenhouseControls(java.lang.String dumpFile)
                                                    throws java.lang.Exception
        restoreGreenhouseControls() Method Restores object from dump.out file Uses ObjectInputStream to restore serialized object
        Parameters:
        dumpFile - The dump.out file you want to restore from
        Returns:
        GreenhouseControls object
        Throws:
        java.io.StreamCorruptedException - if the stream header is incorrect.
        java.io.IOException - if and I/O error occurs while writing stream header.
        java.lang.SecurityException - if untrusted subclass illegally overrides security-sensitive methods.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if in is null.
        java.lang.ClassNotFoundException - Class of a serialized object cannot be found.
        java.io.InvalidClassException - Something is wrong with a class used by serialization.
        java.io.StreamCorruptedException - Control information in the stream is inconsistent.
        java.io.OptionalDataException - Primitive data was found in the stream instead of objects.
        java.io.IOException - Any of the usual Input/Output related exceptions.
        java.lang.Exception

      • restartEvents

        public void restartEvents()
        restartEvents() Method Starts the Events again that were loaded from the dump.out file Creates a new ArrayList of Threads, iterates through gcEvents to see if any events haven't been attempted, if they haven't been attempted then they will be Threaded and ran.
